title: 108_hr3109
content: The Act may be cited as the "Celia Cruz Commemorative Coin Act". Celia Cruz, known as "The Queen of Salsa," started singing in Havana, Cuba at 14. She studied music theory and became a successful recording artist in the 1950s. Cruz fled Cuba in 1960 with her husband to escape Fidel Castro's regime, eventually becoming a naturalized American citizen. Her career spanned over 5 decades, recording over 70 records. Celia Cruz, known as "The Queen of Salsa," recorded over 70 records during her career, earning multiple Grammy Awards, Latin Grammy Awards, and a Billboard Magazine Lifetime Achievement Award in 1995. She was also honored with a Lifetime Achievement Award by the Smithsonian Institution and received the National Medal of the Arts from President Clinton in 1994. Cruz was a champion of freedom and artistic expression, dedicating herself to helping others. In 2002, the Celia Cruz Foundation was established to provide financial aid to low-income individuals, realizing her dream. In 2008, the world will commemorate the 5th anniversary of Celia Cruz's death, honoring her achievements in music and her charitable legacy. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury shall mint $1 silver coins and half dollar clad coins in honor of Celia Cruz. The $1 coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver. The half dollar coins will weigh 11.34 grams, have a diameter of 1.205 inches, and meet specifications for half dollar coins. The coins minted under this Act will be legal tender and considered numismatic items under United States Code. The coins minted under this Act will feature a design emblematic of Celia Cruz and her legacy, with inscriptions including the year "2008" and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and the Celia Cruz Foundation, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from a single US Mint facility starting January 1, 2008, with minting ending on December 31, 2008. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted at a reasonable discount. Marketing efforts will be done in cooperation with the Celia Cruz. The Secretary, in cooperation with the Celia Cruz Foundation, will develop and implement a marketing program to promote and sell the coins issued under this Act in the United States and internationally. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES. Sales of coins minted under this Act will include a surcharge of $10 per $1 coin and $3 per half dollar coin. Surcharges received will be promptly paid to the Celia Cruz Foundation for supporting underprivileged music students and cancer-fighting efforts. The Foundation will be audited for the amounts received.
